review_title: Wonderful learning experience, not so wonderful upper management

pros: I loved working in healthcare and having the opportunity to bring the latest healthcare news and research to the public. I had wonderful managers and mentors who believed in me. The benefits were phenomenal!
cons: After Dr. McConnell was hired as the new CEO, a round of new management was hired in multiple departments throughout the hospital. In what is now called the Communication, Marketing and Media department - multiple upper management positions were snuffed for promotion and a new set of management was hired from outside NC. Slowly you saw people being pushed out of their jobs - many for no reason other than the new management wanted to hire new employees they could "control" better. I know several people still working in this department long for the old days when all you needed was to be good at your job to get ahead. Now its a game of office politics that no one knows how to navigate. Upper management takes credit for work done by others and many are left without getting the credit they deserve. Good luck to those who still work there.

review_title: Employed at Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center for 28 years, recently retired

The employees were respected bu the company, salaries and benefits were good, and it was a great place to work..
cons: Due to changes in the healthcare system and research funding, a lot of people, including faculty, who had worked there for a lot of years, through thick and thin, lost their jobs while the CEO and Senior Management continue to reap the benefits (along with the Board of Directors).  Employee benefits were cut, support staff has been cut or displaced into another position, and salaries have been revamped at a lower rate.

review_title: Terrible and getting worse every day
job_title: Assistant Professor, Internal Medicine in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Patients, colleagues, lots of family involment
cons: This place is horrible. The IT system is cumbersome. It takes forever for orders to be fulfilled due to staffing cuts. On weekends it's almost impossible to get a timely consult. It almost got to the point where I ordered a stat ECG where I had to hook up the leads myself. The executives are overly preoccupied with construction projects to the point where all they care about is bricks and building completion dates. From my end of things, the money from insurance is funding the building craze at the cost to patient care. The executives only seem to care about completing projects for bullet points on their resumes rather than the patients. Many of the experienced Professors have been cut or asked to leave. The only folks here who seem to think that this place is 'great' or 'good' are the HR recruiters. The executives blame the government for chances to healthcare but the tanking of this place falls squarely on the shoulders of the execs. I go home at night worrying that I'll be named in a lawsuit due to the low staffing .

pros: Non-Management and most lower management great to work with.  One Big Family..  There's help if you need it. p

New management, executive level management,  now have the attitude that if you an issue with whats going on you can leave and we'll find someone to take your place.  This is also passed along to lower management and if they don't live by these rules the same thing can happen to them.  

If they want to get rid of you now they make up stuff or use the smallest details and put it in your employee file.  Then they can pull these comments back up at anytime and use them against you.  Since NC is a right to work state you have no legal way to defend yourself....

pros: I've been here over a year and have nothing positive to say about this place. My manager brags about how much he makes though so they must be doing well by him.
cons: I hope this saves someone else the trouble of thinking they found a good job when it really isn't: There is no HR team for the Hawthorne Inn and the management team seems to make decisions based on their own personal agendas or whims. They have taken away our on-call pay but we still have to be available to them on evenings and weekends and cannot make personal plans.  When we do have to go in we cannot earn overtime and instead have to trade it for time off at a later date.  They have been promising to make me full time since I started so I can get benefits but then always make an excuse.  My manager rubs in in my face about how much money he makes and all the great benefits he has, meanwhile my family and I have no health benefits because they don't keep their promises.

review_title: I would never work there again.

I'll also say that department as a whole does not appreciate it's employees.  You could work there for years and they will still bring someone else in and give them your position and hours after "you" have trained them.  They are also temperamental and will add your name to the schedule and not communicate that to you so they can write you up for missing work and they will also lie about it!

pros: Wonderful physicians who care about patients, and equally wonderful nurses and non-medical staff who are great to work with.

review_title: Excellent place to work with great people to work with.

cons: We are a closed academic medical center and often new people are unaware of how that system works and have a hard time adjusting to it.  However, it also has a lot of benefits as well.

review_title: used to be good but now a terrible place to work
pros: city of winston salem, colleagues who work here.
cons: The current management is only concerned with saving their jobs and salaries. Last year this place suffered a $60-70 million loss. The administration has started paycuts upto 15% every year and has fired a lot of faculty members. While many employees are getting paycuts, the senior administration has not taken any paycut despite the medical Centre suffering severe losses.  It seems like a new administrator is being appointed every other month. There is no support for facilities and for research.   People are leaving en masse or waiting for a job offer to leave. The morale of the faculty is at its lowest in the last 10 years. Not a good place for scientific research. They are even starting to make cuts in the number of teaching hours to the medical students. I really feel awful for the medical students who are paying greater than $55,000 annually to go to medical school here.

review_title: It is like an assembly line of patients

Hospital leadership is a revolving door.

pros: Colleagues, pay, and modern teh
cons: Lately, supervisors started using hardball tactics to save money when layoffs occur. They will make up a cause to fire; threaten to report you to the board of nursing, and offer the option to resign as an out to avoid reporting you to the state. The claims are usually totally bogus. The end result is that by forcing you to resign instead of just doing a layoff is that  you then don't qualify for unemployment , so the state then doesn't bill the hospital, and the hospital saves money. This is now being practiced in multiple departments. END RESULT - WAKE SAVES MONEY BY COMMITING FRAUD. Unfortunately supervisors are under pressure to do this and they can not be trusted.

pros: Wake Forest Baptist Health is a growing system with opportunities to get involved as the system evolves.

Healthcare inevitably involves politics and conflicting missions based on your job's perspective- that is especially true at WFBH due to the numerous missions (clinical, academic, research).  Until the system is truly integrated that will remain true.  

There are additional growing pains as the system transforms itself from an Academic Medical Center to a health system.  These growing pains will continue until the system is well established.

pros: Love the work. work with hospital staff, Reference lab clients and patients and their families
cons: Very difficult to get the tools needed to the job. we have been waiting and testing lists for 15 years and a complete list is still not available. No room for advancement. Jobs are given predominantly by playing politics. Many times the skills required to do the job are absent from the candidate chosen--even certifications are absent in some instances.

pros: The interview and tasks at hand were not difficult to perform and complete.
cons:
This is specific to the department that I was in. Please understand that this might not reflect overall but it is important to point out. I do not think Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center has many employees that are open minded. There was definitely a divide between me and the other people that worked there since day one. They had all known each other growing up and were from one area and they really emphasized that I was the other. There would be stipulations that only applied to me. For example, some form of noting where you are was present but no one filled it out and I was the only one reprimanded because of it . Headphones were something very casually worn, yet I would be called into the manager on site to stop - while everyone else continued to enjoy this perk. And the real kicker, I had been called into the office and reprimanded because someone complained that I was 'taking too many pee breaks.' After that point I was genuinely disturbed over this meeting. I had no idea what level of disrespect I would receive. It was an embarrassing experience and I really hope no one else has to go through what I did. I sometimes remember it and it makes me cringe. I wish I reported it but I needed the job at the time. I was scared. Too bad now.

Also, no growth in the job. No going above and beyond, adding publications, leveling up from one tech level to another.

Also, I did not get fired, I left. I think it is important to point out that I did the work but they just did not like me and I needed to find stability elsewhere.
